I threw together a quick demo of a solarized light theme:

https://github.com/jsha/rust/pull/new/solarized

https://rustdoc.crud.net/jsha/solarized/std/string/struct.String.html
https://rustdoc.crud.net/jsha/solarized/std/vec/struct.Vec.html
https://rustdoc.crud.net/jsha/solarized/std/io/trait.Read.html
https://rustdoc.crud.net/jsha/solarized/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html

Based off of https://ethanschoonover.com/solarized/. Not complete - I'd still like to update some of the notice colors and the search-focus colors to be in palette. But I think it looks pretty nice so far.
I'm not sure it's a good idea to add another theme for the moment: they are very high maintenance effort and we're in the middle of a lot of changes. Once it's settled down, why not though!
Hmm, I feel like Solarized fits better as a code editing theme. The contrast looks too low to me. (FWIW, I don't usually like Solarized with code editing either, so I may be biased here.)
And I agree with Guillaume about the high maintenance part. I think we should try to figure out a way to make themes lower-effort, perhaps just by continuing to incrementally clean up rustdoc's CSS.

so I actually have an idea for how to make themes lower-maintenance: CSS variables! https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Using_CSS_custom_properties

You can see an example if you click through on the solarized branch I shared. You can also see a very nice example if you look at the CSS for https://www.powerlanguage.co.uk/wordle/ (ideally after playing a couple of words).

The idea is we would define semantic names like --foreground: black on the root element, and themes can override it with e.g. --foreground: white. So instead of having to override a bunch of rules, they override just a few variables.
Yeah, the thought of using CSS variables more has crossed my mind too :)
They seem to be supported in almost all browsers, except for IE and a couple others
Variables reduce it a bit, but if you look at ayu, a lot of its CSS isn't shared with other themes, so it won't solve all problems unfortunately (but still make the situation better!)
